home.subtitle: Your guide to secure information handling

guide.intro: Unsure how to handle sensitive information? Our classification guide helps you make the right decisions through a simple and effective checklist.
guide.details: Isotron is designed to assist employees in classifying sensitive data according to ISO 27001 standards. By following a decision tree, users can answer a series of questions that lead to a classification report, ensuring compliance and proper handling of information.

training.intro: Start your learning journey with our interactive training modules and test your knowledge through our tailored quizzes.
training.details: The training modules are designed to provide comprehensive knowledge about ISO 27001 compliance, helping employees understand the importance of data security and the steps necessary to maintain it. Each module includes quizzes to reinforce learning and ensure retention of key concepts.

understandingSecurity.description: Learn about different security classification levels.

courseOverview.title: Course Overview
courseOverview.description: In this course, you will learn about the different security levels used to classify sensitive information. Understanding these levels is crucial for ensuring that information is properly protected according to its sensitivity and importance.

learningObjectives.title: Learning Objectives
learningObjectives.item1: Understand the purpose of security classification levels
learningObjectives.item2: Identify the common classification levels and their meanings
learningObjectives.item3: Apply appropriate security levels to different types of information
learningObjectives.item4: Recognize the responsibilities associated with handling information at each level

public.title: Public
public.description: Information that can be freely shared with the public and poses no risk if disclosed. Examples include marketing materials, public reports, and general information on company websites.

internal.title: Internal Use Only
internal.description: Information meant for employees and contractors only, but would pose minimal risk if disclosed. Examples include internal newsletters, non-sensitive emails, and general operational documents.

confidential.title: Confidential
confidential.description: Sensitive information that must be protected and would cause harm to the organization if disclosed. Examples include financial records, business strategies, and intellectual property.

highlyConfidential.title: Highly Confidential
highlyConfidential.description: Extremely sensitive information that would cause severe damage if disclosed. Examples include customer PII, authentication credentials, and trade secrets.

bestPractices.title: Best Practices
bestPractices.item1: Always mark documents with their classification level
bestPractices.item2: When in doubt, assign a higher level of classification
bestPractices.item3: Regularly review and reclassify information as needed
bestPractices.item4: Follow appropriate handling procedures for each level
bestPractices.item5: Report any potential security breaches immediately

scenario1.title: Scenario 1:
scenario1.description: A document describing the company's standard operating procedures for handling customer support tickets.
scenario1.feedback: Internal procedures should be classified as Internal. While not sensitive, they're not meant for public consumption.

scenario2.title: Scenario 2:
scenario2.description: A spreadsheet containing customer names, addresses, and purchase history.
scenario2.feedback: Customer data contains private information and should be classified as Confidential.

scenario3.title: Scenario 3:
scenario3.description: A file containing database passwords and API keys for the company's main services.
scenario3.feedback: Authentication credentials require the highest level of protection - Highly Confidential.

public.title: Public Information
public.item1: Can be freely shared internally and externally
public.item3: Can be published on public websites
public.item4: Examples: Marketing materials, press releases, public annual reports

internal.title: Internal Information
internal.item2: Avoid sharing with external parties without approval
internal.item4: Examples: Internal procedures, employee directories, meeting minutes

confidential.title: Confidential Information
confidential.item1: Share only with authorized individuals who need to know
confidential.item2: Use secure methods for sharing (encrypted email, secure file sharing)
confidential.item4: Do not leave printed copies unattended
confidential.item5: Examples: Customer data, financial reports, business strategies

highlyConfidential.title: Highly Confidential Information
highlyConfidential.item1: Strictest access controls - only specific authorized individuals
highlyConfidential.item2: Always use encryption when storing or transmitting
highlyConfidential.item3: Track all access and actions taken on the information
highlyConfidential.item5: Use secure rooms for discussions involving this information
highlyConfidential.item6: Examples: Trade secrets, authentication credentials, strategic acquisitions

physical.title: Physical Security
physical.item1: Use the clean desk policy - don't leave sensitive documents visible
physical.item2: Lock away sensitive information when not in use
physical.item4: Be aware of your surroundings when discussing sensitive information

digital.title: Digital Security
digital.item1: Use strong passwords and multi-factor authentication
digital.item3: Be cautious with email attachments and links
digital.item4: Lock your computer when away from your desk
digital.item5: Only use approved cloud services for sensitive data

incident.title: Incident Response
incident.item2: Know who to contact in case of a suspected breach
incident.item3: Document any potential exposure of sensitive information
incident.item4: Follow company procedures for incident response

iso27001.title: ISO 27001 Fundamentals
iso27001.description: Introduction to ISO 27001 principles and practices

ismsBasics.title: ISMS Basics
ismsBasics.description: Learn about information security management systems.

whatIsISMS.title: What is an ISMS?
whatIsISMS.description: An Information Security Management System (ISMS) is a systematic approach to managing sensitive company information so that it remains secure. It encompasses people, processes, and technology.
whatIsISMS.definition: Definition: An ISMS is a framework of policies and procedures that includes all legal, physical, and technical controls involved in an organization's information risk management processes.

isoAndISMS.title: ISO 27001 and ISMS
isoAndISMS.description: ISO 27001 is the international standard that describes best practice for an ISMS. It provides a framework for establishing, implementing, operating, monitoring, reviewing, maintaining, and improving an ISMS.

plan.title: Plan
plan.description: Establish ISMS policy, objectives, processes, and procedures

do.title: Do
do.description: Implement and operate the ISMS policy, controls, processes, and procedures

check.title: Check
check.description: Monitor and review the ISMS, measuring process performance against policy and objectives

act.title: Act
act.description: Take corrective and preventive actions, based on internal audit results, to achieve continual improvement

policy.title: Information Security Policy
policy.description: Sets the direction and expresses management support for information security

riskAssessment.title: Risk Assessment
riskAssessment.description: Systematic process to identify, analyze, and evaluate information security risks

controls.title: Security Controls
controls.description: Safeguards or countermeasures to avoid, detect, counteract, or minimize security risks

soa.title: Statement of Applicability (SoA)
soa.description: Document describing which controls are relevant and applicable to the organization's ISMS

audits.title: Internal Audits
audits.description: Regular checks to ensure the ISMS is functioning as expected and identify improvements

review.title: Management Review
review.description: Regular assessment of the ISMS by top management to ensure its continued suitability and effectiveness

options.b: A systematic approach to managing sensitive information and ensuring business continuity

pdcaCycle.title: Question 2: PDCA Cycle

isoPrinciples.question: 3. Which of the following is a fundamental principle in ISO 27001?

options.d: Isolating all systems from external connections

riskAssessment.question: 4. What role does risk assessment play in ISO 27001?

feedback.riskAssessment: Risk assessment is an essential component for establishing an ISMS.
feedback.certification: To achieve ISO 27001 certification, an organization must implement an ISMS, conduct internal audits, address non-conformities, and pass an external audit.

riskAssessment.title: Risk Assessment
riskAssessment.description: Learn about risk assessment in ISO 27001.

whatIs.title: What is Risk Assessment?
whatIs.description: Risk assessment is a critical component in ISO 27001 and the foundation for an effective Information Security Management System (ISMS). It involves identifying, analyzing, and evaluating information security risks.
whatIs.definition: Definition: Risk assessment is the overall process of risk identification, risk analysis, and risk evaluation as defined in ISO 27001.

identification.title: 1. Risk Identification
identification.description: Finding, recognizing, and describing risks by identifying assets, threats, existing controls, vulnerabilities, and consequences.

analysis.title: 2. Risk Analysis
analysis.description: Understanding the nature of risk and determining the risk level by assigning values to likelihood and consequence.

evaluation.title: 3. Risk Evaluation
evaluation.description: Comparing risk analysis results with risk criteria to determine if a risk is acceptable or requires treatment.

treatment.title: 4. Risk Treatment
treatment.description: Selecting and implementing options for addressing risk through risk modification (controls), risk acceptance, risk avoidance, or risk transfer.

assets.title: Asset Identification
assets.description: Identifying and categorizing information assets is the first step in risk assessment.
assets.item5: People (staff, customers, users) and their qualifications, skills, and experience

threats.title: Threat Identification
threats.description: Identifying potential threat sources and events that could harm assets.

vulnerabilities.title: Vulnerability Assessment
vulnerabilities.description: Identifying weaknesses in assets that could be exploited by threats.

qualitative.title: Qualitative Analysis
qualitative.description: Uses descriptive scales (High, Medium, Low) to describe the likelihood and consequence of risks.

quantitative.title: Quantitative Analysis
quantitative.description: Assigns numerical values to risks, often in monetary terms or specific scoring scales.

modify.title: Modify (Reduce)
modify.description: Implement controls to reduce risk likelihood or consequence.

accept.title: Accept
accept.description: Make an informed decision to accept the risk without further action.

avoid.title: Avoid
avoid.description: Decide not to proceed with the activity that introduces the risk.

transfer.title: Transfer
transfer.description: Share the risk with another party (e.g., insurance, outsourcing).

quiz.title: Knowledge Check
quiz.excellent: Excellent! You understand the principles of risk assessment in the context of information security.

options.a: A one-time evaluation of security threats
options.b: A technical audit of IT systems
options.c: The overall process of identifying, analyzing, and evaluating information security risks
options.d: An inventory of security software and hardware

riskManagementProcess.title: Question 2: Risk Management Process
riskManagementProcess.question: 2. What are the main steps in the risk management process?

assetIdentification.title: Question 3: Asset Identification
assetIdentification.question: 3. Which of the following is typically NOT considered during asset identification?

options.a: Information assets such as databases and files
options.b: Physical assets such as servers and network equipment
options.c: Intangible assets such as reputation and company image

threatTypes.title: Question 4: Types of Threats
threatTypes.question: 4. Which of the following is a complete list of common threat types?

options.a: Human errors, technical failures, physical events, and malicious attacks

riskTreatment.title: Question 5: Risk Treatment Options
riskTreatment.question: 5. What are the four main options for risk treatment in ISO 27001?

feedback.riskAssessmentDefinition: Risk assessment is the overall process of identifying, analyzing, and evaluating information security risks.
feedback.riskManagementProcess: The risk management process includes identification, analysis, evaluation, and treatment of risks.
feedback.assetIdentification: All information assets should be identified and valued as part of a risk assessment.
feedback.threatTypes: Common threats include human errors, technical failures, physical events, and malicious attacks.
feedback.riskTreatment: The four primary options for risk treatment are: modify (reduce), accept, avoid, and transfer.

about.title: About Isotron
about.subtitle: A comprehensive platform for information security classification based on ISO 27001 standards
about.content: This project aims to help organizations properly classify and protect sensitive information in accordance with information security best practices.

iso27001.title: ISO 27001 Integration
iso27001.description: Our project is built around the principles of ISO 27001, the international standard for information security management. While this standard is comprehensive and often perceived as difficult to implement, our tool makes document classification straightforward and accessible. The standard provides a framework for:

points.isms: Establishing and maintaining an information security management system (ISMS)
points.approach: Systematic approach to managing sensitive company information

classification.title: Intuitive Classification Guide
classification.description: Develop a user-friendly guide for proper information classification

iso27001Framework.title: ISO 27001 Framework
iso27001Framework.subtitle: An international standard for managing information security, providing a systematic approach to information management and risk mitigation.

introduction.title: Introduction to ISO 27001
introduction.description: ISO 27001 is an international standard for managing information security. It provides a framework for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving an information security management system (ISMS).

items.dataBreaches: Prevents data breaches that expose personal or business-sensitive information
items.legalConsequences: Avoids legal consequences due to non-compliance with regulations
items.financialLosses: Reduces financial losses due to fines, lawsuits, or reputational damage
items.operationalContinuity: Maintains operational continuity by protecting against system failures or cyberattacks

policies.title: Information Security Policies
policies.description: Policies that define the approach to managing information security within the organization.

organization.title: Organization of Information Security
organization.description: The framework for managing information security responsibilities and processes.

assets.title: Asset Management
assets.description: Processes for managing and protecting information assets.

access.title: Access Control
access.description: Mechanisms to ensure that access to information is restricted to authorized users.

crypto.title: Cryptography
crypto.description: Use of cryptographic techniques to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and authenticity of information.

physical.title: Physical and Environmental Security
physical.description: Measures to protect physical facilities and equipment from unauthorized access and environmental hazards.

annex8.title: Annex A.8  Asset Management
annex8.description: Ensures that information assets are identified and managed appropriately throughout their lifecycle. This includes conducting a thorough assessment to identify all data assets within the organization and categorizing data based on sensitivity levels to apply appropriate protection measures.

annex10.title: Annex A.10  Cryptography
annex10.description: Requires the use of cryptographic controls to protect data confidentiality, integrity, and authenticity. This involves encrypting data at rest and in transit, and developing robust key management policies to safeguard encryption keys.

annex11.title: Annex A.11  Physical Security
annex11.description: Focuses on securing physical storage environments against unauthorized access and environmental threats. This includes ensuring secure storage locations for servers and hard drives, and implementing measures to protect physical facilities and equipment.
